entry.title: Combined summary - Proposal: Bundled payments
entry.summary: Thomas Voegtlin has proposed an extension to BOLT-11, the Lightning Network specification. This extension would allow invoices to contain two bundled payments with distinct preimages and amounts. The proposal is primarily targeted at services that require a prepayment of mining fees for non-custodian exchanges, such as submarine swaps and JIT channels. The goal is to level the competition between Lightning service providers by enabling reverse submarine swap payments to come from any wallet, rather than requiring a dedicated client like Loop.The semantics of bundled payments in BOLT-11 involve the invoice containing two preimages and two amounts: a prepayment and a main payment. The receiver of the invoice would need to wait until all the Hashed Time-Locked Contracts (HTLCs) of both payments have arrived before fulfilling the HTLCs of the pre-payment. If the main payment does not arrive, the receiver should fail the pre-payment with a MPP (Multi-Path Payments) timeout. Once the HTLCs of both payments have arrived, the receiver can fulfill the HTLCs of the pre-payment and broadcast the on-chain transaction.Matt Corallo expresses skepticism about adding new interoperable changes to BOLT-11 at this stage. He suggests focusing on specifying a standard way of doing swaps, potentially built on onion messages (OMs) for increased privacy. He also mentions that submarine swaps enable adding receiving capacity to a channel. Thomas asks whether the distinction between splice-out and submarine swaps is necessary, to which Matt responds that submarine swaps do provide benefits in terms of adding receiving capacity.Thomas also mentions that combining pre-payment of the mining fee with 0-conf (zero-confirms) is possible, but he believes that even with BOLT-12, 0-conf will still be used. Bastien suggests extending Bolt 12 instead of updating Bolt 11, as it would require new sender code. He discusses three strategies for providing JIT liquidity and suggests considering pre-paying fees if 0-conf is no longer used.In response to Matt's concerns, Thomas states that it may not be too late to add a new feature to BOLT-11. Lightning Labs and ACINQ, the company behind Loop, have incentives to support the proposal. He suggests making the feature optional during a transition period and provides a possible implementation. The decision to make the feature required or optional would ultimately be up to the service provider.Overall, the discussion revolves around Thomas's proposal to extend BOLT-11 with a feature that allows invoices to contain two bundled payments. This would address limitations and vulnerabilities faced by lightning service providers, enhance competition, and promote non-custodial solutions for certain services. However, there are considerations regarding the implementation, compatibility with existing protocols, and the need for a standard way of doing swaps.
